author: @earlygamegg
title: Cake vs. Critter: PETA Wants To Revolutionize
text:
Every year, a bewildered groundhog is paraded in front of adoring crowds to predict the weather – but PETA thinks it's time to give the little guy a break and let a cake do the job instead.
Groundhog Day – the annual tradition where a groggy rodent is yanked from its burrow to predict the weather – might be due for a makeover. At least, if PETA has anything to say about it. Their latest proposal? Retire Punxsutawney Phil and replace him with… a cake.
A Sweeter Groundhog Day?
Thanks to Groundhog Day (yes, the Bill Murray movie that somehow feels autobiographical every February), this bizarre ritual is now known far beyond Pennsylvania. Every year on February 2, Phil emerges – or rather, is dramatically lifted – to determine whether winter is here to stay or spring is on its way. Shadow means six more weeks of misery, no shadow means warmer days ahead.
Charming? Sure. But PETA says it's time to let Phil enjoy his well-deserved retirement, free of cameras and weather-predicting responsibilities he never signed up for.
Trade A Groundhog To A Cake
PETA sent a letter to the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club with a proposal: replace Phil with a cake.
Their reasoning? Groundhogs are not known for their love of public speaking. In the wild, they dig elaborate underground tunnels, chatter with their fellow marmots, and occasionally climb trees. What they don't do – at least not voluntarily – is performing meteorological stunts for an audience. As PETA President Ingrid Newkirk puts it: "Phil has been denied all of that for a tired old gimmick."
And so, PETA's solution: a cake, freshly baked and (presumably) humanely sourced. They even promise to send a new vegan cake every year, complete with a foolproof weather prediction system. Blue filling? Winter is dragging on. Pink filling? Spring is coming. Basically, it's a Groundhog Day-themed gender reveal party, minus the explosions and accidental forest fires.
Will the tradition be replaced by an annual dessert ritual? Probably not. Let's face it – watching a cake get sliced might be just as exciting as seeing a slightly confused groundhog held aloft like a discount Simba. Personally, I like cake. And I would gladly give Phil his well-deserved retirement.

author: Elisabetta Piqué
title: Asumió el embajador argentino en el Vaticano y relató su primer encuentro con el papa Francisco - LA NACION
text:
ROMA.- Tal como se esperaba, el nuevo embajador argentino ante la Santa Sede, Luis Pablo María Beltramino , presentó este viernes cartas credenciales ante el papa Francisco en una audiencia en el Palacio Apostólico del Vaticano. Diplomático de carrera y abogado que sucedió a la también diplomática de carrera María Fernanda Silva, Beltramino vistió para la ocasión un riguroso frack, como indica el protocolo para este tipo de audiencias que marcan el inicio de la oficialización del nuevo cargo. El flamante embajador, de 63 años y que es católico practicante, fue recibido junto a su esposa, Mercedes Schang, a quienes pasaron a buscar por la embajada gentilhombres del Vaticano, como es tradición.
“Fue un encuentro muy bueno, muy cálido y jovial, tanto en cuanto a la ceremonia, como en cuanto al contenido”, dijo a LA NACION Beltramino, que contó que era la primera vez que se encontraba con el Pontífice, algo “muy especial en lo personal y en lo profesional”.
Durante el encuentro, el flamante nuevo embajador le manifestó al Papa “el interés de continuar desarrollando la agenda bilateral, en el marco de las excelentes relaciones históricas entre la Argentina y la Santa Sede”. También se habló de la Argentina y de las cuestiones más relevantes de la agenda internacional, en un mundo convulsionado.
Preguntado si hubo novedades sobre un posible viaje a su madre patria, que el Papa dijo varias veces que desea hacer a fin de este año y que es una asignatura pendiente, Beltramino fue muy escueto. “Ya está invitado, esperamos que venga y es una decisión del Santo Padre cuándo y cómo”, dijo.
Hasta hace unos meses embajador en Vietnam, Beltramino, hijo del destacado diplomático, Juan Carlos Beltramino, tiene vasta experiencia: se desempeñó como subsecretario de Política Exterior, dependiente de la Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores que condujo Jorge Faurie durante la presidencia de Mauricio Macri. Ejerció asimsimo funciones en las embajadas argentinas en los Estados Unidos y en los Países Bajos . Además, fue representante alterno ante la Organización Internacional para la Prohibición de las Armas Químicas, y ante los organismos internacionales jurídicos, como la Corte Penal Internacional, la Corte Permanente de Arbitraje y la Conferencia de Derecho Internacional Privado con sede en La Haya.
La semana pasada Beltramino había tenido su presentación en sociedad en una misa solemne que se celebró en la Iglesia Nacional Argentina de esta capital para conmemorar el 25 de Mayo.
El papa Francisco ALBERTO PIZZOLI - AFP

author: Rosa Soto
title: En Ecuador disponen nueva orden de prisión preventiva contra exjefe de la Judicatura
text:
EL NUEVO DIARIO, QUITO. – Un tribunal de Ecuador emitió este jueves una nueva orden de prisión preventiva por supuesta «obstrucción de la justicia» contra un exjefe del Consejo de la Judicatura, Wilman Terán, quien se encuentra en prisión por otro caso que indaga la presunta infiltración del narcotráfico en el sistema judicial.
La Fiscalía General del Estado informó que el juez Luis Rivera emitió órdenes de prisión preventiva, con fines de investigación, contra Terán y otros dos vocales del Consejo de la Judicatura, Javier M. y Maribel B., acusados por el Ministerio Público como «autores directos» del supuesto delito.
Indicaron que también han sido procesados como «cómplices» otros funcionarios del Consejo de la Judicatura identificados como Andrés J., Marcela V., Carlos G. y Katherine L., agregó la fuente.
Al concluir la audiencia, el juez Rivera acogió el pedido de la Fiscalía, dictó prisión preventiva contra Terán y Xavier M., mientras que a los otros cinco procesados les prohibió salir del país, presentarse periódicamente ante el tribunal y usar un grillete electrónico.
El magistrado también ordenó la retención de los valores y cuentas bancarias de los imputados, y les prohibió enajenar los bienes que estuvieran a su nombre.
Paralelamente, el juez Rivera emitió medidas de protección a favor del juez Walter Macías, el fiscal general subrogante, Wilson Toainga, y la agente fiscal Alexandra Zurita, por considerar que el Consejo de la Judicatura pudiera ejercer acciones de persecución e intimidación contra ellos por este caso.
Toainga, en la audiencia, relató que esta investigación fiscal comenzó en 2022 ante un supuesto delito de tráfico de influencias que salpicaba a exvocales del Consejo de la Judicatura como Juan José M. y Maribel B.
El caso recayó en el juez Macías, quien fue recusado por Maribel B., aunque la acción de la exvocal fue rechazada el 11 de mayo de 2023, horas antes de que la Judicatura suspendiera al juez Macías, en una sesión de esa entidad que, según la Fiscalía, estuvo marcada por irregularidades.
Para el Ministerio Público, aunque las entidades del Estado tienen atribuciones propias, éstas no pueden ser usadas de forma ilegítima en función de impedir la acción de los jueces.
La Fiscalía añadió que el delito de obstrucción de la justicia está tipificado y sancionado en un artículo del Código Orgánico Integral Penal.
El pasado 19 de diciembre, Terán, que había sido detenido pocos días antes tras una investigación fiscal relacionado con la supuesta infiltración del crimen organizado en el sistema judicial, presentaba desde la cárcel su carta de dimisión como presidente del Consejo de la Judicatura.
Ese mismo día, el Consejo de Administración Legislativa de la Asamblea Nacional (Parlamento) resolvía admitir a trámite una solicitud de juicio político contra Terán, así como contra los exvocales de la Judicatura Xavier Muñoz y Maribel Barrero, acusados por un presunto incumplimiento de funciones.
Terán fue detenido en el marco del denominado caso «Metástasis», sobre una presunta trama de corrupción en los sistemas judicial, carcelario y policial por infiltración y sobornos del narcotráfico.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: No swim advisory issued for Intracoastal Waterway near Boca Raton
text: The Florida Department of Health in Palm Beach County issued a no swim advisory on Thursday for the Intracoastal Waterway near Boca Raton. The health alert was issued following a recent wastewater spill into the waterway near 1629 Royal Palm Way. Health officials said drinking water is not affected. Residents and visitors in the area are urged to take precautions when in contact with the Intracoastal Waterway officials said. The city of Boca Raton is coordinating testing and cleanup actions with the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, the health department said. Water contaminated with elevated fecal bacteria poses health risks to humans. Officials said microbes in fecal bacteria could cause gastrointestinal issues and other conditions. Anyone who comes into contact with the water in this area should wash thoroughly, especially before eating or drinking. Extra precautions should be taken for children, older adults, as well as people with weakened immune systems, officials said.

author: Murilo da Silva
title: Trabalhadores da PepsiCo fazem greve contra a escala 6×1
text:
Motivados pela discussão do fim da escala 6×1 no Congresso Nacional , os trabalhadores da PepsiCo, companhia que reúne marcas como Pepsi, Gatorade, Doritos, Toddy, Ruffles, Cheetos, Elma Chips e Quaker (aveias e grãos), estão em greve desde domingo (24).
A decisão foi votada em assembleia pelos trabalhadores, que são representados pelo STILASP (Sindicato dos Trabalhadores nas Indústrias de Laticínios e Alimentação de São Paulo e Região), nas fábricas de Itaquera, na zona leste de São Paulo, e na cidade de Sorocaba.
De acordo com o sindicato, a greve é necessária pela postura intransigente da empresa em dialogar. Conforme colocam, a PepsiCo tenta implementar a jornada 6×1 e 6×2 de forma inflexível.
Leia mais: “Escala 6×1 é incompatível com a dignidade”, diz líder comerciário sobre PEC
“Na última reunião, realizada no dia 22, a empresa ignorou nossa proposta, reafirmando um comportamento que consideramos inaceitável, visto que estamos passando por uma mobilização nacional pelo fim de jornadas de trabalho desumanas. O STILASP é contra as jornadas 6×1 e 6×2, nossa luta é para que todos os trabalhadores tenham qualidade de vida e saúde mental”, aponta o sindicato em nota.
O TRT-2 (Tribunal Regional do Trabalho da 2º Região) mediou uma conciliação após a realização de três assembleias com os trabalhadores de São Paulo – já realizadas. Dessa maneira, os trabalhos podem voltar até a nova audiência, marcada para 02 de dezembro, quando as partes deverão apresentar, no mínimo, duas novas propostas de jornadas de trabalho.
“Continuaremos unidos em busca de uma jornada de trabalho digna, que nos permita desfrutar dos momentos de descanso com nossas famílias”, coloca o sindicato.

author: Jamie Young
title: Grangemouth oil refinery to close in 2024, risking 400 jobs and increasing UK fuel imports
text:
Scotland’s last remaining oil refinery at Grangemouth will close between April and June next year, resulting in the loss of 400 jobs and leaving the UK with only a handful of refineries. The closure, announced by Petroineos—a joint venture between Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s Ineos and PetroChina—comes as domestic demand for motor fuels declines, exacerbated by the forthcoming ban on new petrol and diesel cars.
Frank Demay, Chief Executive at Petroineos Refining, stated that the demand for key fuels produced at Grangemouth has already started to decline. “With a ban on new petrol and diesel cars due to come into force within the next decade, we foresee that the market for those fuels will shrink,” Demay said. The company cited the costs of maintaining a refinery built nearly a century ago as a significant factor in the decision.
The announcement has sparked criticism from political leaders and unions. UK Energy Secretary Ed Miliband expressed deep disappointment, while his Scottish counterpart, Gillian Martin, and union leaders condemned the decision as “industrial vandalism.” Grangemouth currently accounts for about 14% of the UK’s overall refining capacity, supplying motor fuels and other products across Scotland and northern England. Although the UK remains a net exporter of petrol, it relies on imports for diesel and jet fuel.
To mitigate the impact of the closure, Petroineos plans to establish an import and export fuel terminal at the site, ensuring continued supply to forecourts and other customers. The refinery has faced ongoing financial challenges, with accumulated losses of $775 million since 2011 despite a $1.2 billion investment. Its ageing infrastructure, originally opened in 1924, is less efficient than that of overseas competitors and requires an additional £40 million to remain operational beyond next spring.
Approximately 75 workers will stay on to operate the new terminal, while up to 280 jobs will be lost in the three months following the closure. Another 100 employees will remain for up to a year to begin decommissioning, with a small number staying on for longer to oversee further decommissioning and demolition efforts.
The UK and Scottish governments have commissioned studies to explore potential future uses for the refinery, with options including hydrogen, biofuels, and sustainable aviation fuel. However, these alternatives are unlikely to be implemented before the refinery shuts down. In response, the governments have announced a joint investment plan, adding £20 million to the previously announced £80 million Falkirk and Grangemouth Growth Deal, aimed at funding new growth projects in the area. The UK government also plans to explore using its National Wealth Fund to support alternative uses for the refinery site.
The closure is expected to have significant ripple effects on the wider economy, impacting numerous small businesses reliant on the refinery. Hisashi Kuboyama from the Federation of Small Businesses in Scotland highlighted the broader consequences, warning that “the knock-on effect on the supply chain will have an impact on numerous small businesses across the length and breadth of the country, putting many more jobs than the 400 on site at risk.”
Sharon Graham, General Secretary of the Unite union, criticised both Petroineos and politicians for failing to safeguard the workforce until alternative employment opportunities are secured. “This dedicated workforce has been let down by Petroineos and by the politicians in Westminster and Holyrood who have failed to guarantee production until alternative jobs are in place,” Graham said. She called on the Labour government to demonstrate its commitment to workers and communities, adding, “The road to net zero cannot be paid for with workers’ jobs.”
The decision to close the refinery does not directly impact other petrochemical operations at the Grangemouth complex, which will continue to operate. However, the closure represents a significant shift in the UK’s energy landscape, further increasing the nation’s reliance on imported fuels and raising questions about the future of the site and the community that depends on it.
